chapter.title: Rogue Protocol Control
chapter.para:
The Rogue Protocol Control Appliance is identified by the
symbol. If the Rogue Protocol Control Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

The Rogue Protocol Control Appliance is used by Administrators to block well known protocols from entering or leaving the protected network. For example, Peer to Peer (P2P) protocols can be blocked from a corporate office or game protocols from a school.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Web Content Control has two tabs. The first tab, covered in section , allow administrators to define which protocols are blocked. The second tab, discussed in , allows administrators to the recent history of blocked protocols.

sect2.title: Protocol Block List
sect2.para: The Protocol Block List, as shown in , allows administrators to choose which protocols to block.

Each protocol is given a logical category, as well as its common-named protocol. To cause a given protocol to be blocked from either entering or leaving your protected network, check the box in the block column. If you only waant to audit your traffic (for example, to see if anyone within the network is participating in file sharing), you can check the log box for that protocol. If log is checked, occurances of the protocol found by ⪚ can be seen in the Even Log (see

As with most Software Appliances within ⪚, administrators can define their own entries in the Protocol Block table. However, this appliance is configured with a regular expression. Configuring regular expressions to match internet protocols is an advanced feature, which will not be covered in this document.
Attempting to create your own entry in the Protocol Block List could result in legitimate traffic being blocked if your regular expression contains errors.
